articles.headline: Sri Lanka Was Warned of Possible Attacks. Why Didn’t It Stop Them?
articles.snippet: The government’s history of bitter infighting appears to have contributed to a spectacular security blunder that led to one of the world’s deadliest terrorist attacks.
articles.abstract: The government’s history of bitter infighting appears to have contributed to a spectacular security blunder that led to one of the world’s deadliest terrorist attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The confidential security memo laid it all out: names, addresses, phone numbers, even the times in the middle of the night that one suspect would visit his wife.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Mujib Mashal and Dharisha Bastians

articles.headline: As Herman Cain Bows Out of Fed Contention, Focus Shifts to Stephen Moore
articles.snippet: Mr. Cain withdrew in the face of allegations of sexual harassment, even as Mr. Moore, the president’s other embattled pick, faced allegations of sexism.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cain withdrew in the face of allegations of sexual harassment, even as Mr. Moore, the president’s other embattled pick, faced allegations of sexism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump announced Monday that Herman Cain, one of his two embattled picks for the Federal Reserve Board, had withdrawn his name from consideration, even as his second candidate came under new scrutiny over his attitudes toward women.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: A Vicious, Untreatable Killer Leaves China Guessing
articles.snippet: African swine fever, which harms pigs but not humans, has swept across the country, the world’s largest pork producer. And the government knows about only some of the cases.
articles.abstract: African swine fever, which harms pigs but not humans, has swept across the country, the world’s largest pork producer. And the government knows about only some of the cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: XIJIAHE, China — The plague’s victims die gruesomely.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Ailin Tang

articles.headline: Pelosi Urges Caution on Impeachment as Some Democrats Push to Begin
articles.snippet: A letter and a conference call by Speaker Nancy Pelosi appeared intended to shore up support for the investigations already begun rather than impeachment proceedings.
articles.abstract: A letter and a conference call by Speaker Nancy Pelosi appeared intended to shore up support for the investigations already begun rather than impeachment proceedings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi, confronting a Democratic divide over the findings of the special counsel, urged her caucus on Monday to hold off impeaching President Trump for now, even as she denounced the “highly unethical and unscrupulous behavior” that she said had dishonored his office.

articles.headline: Elon Musk Predicts Tesla Driverless Taxi Fleet Next Year
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk said Tesla cars would soon drive themselves and serve as robot taxis. But many experts think autonomous cars are at least several years away.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk said Tesla cars would soon drive themselves and serve as robot taxis. But many experts think autonomous cars are at least several years away.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, has made plenty of bold predictions. They don’t always come true.

articles.headline: This Estonian Start-Up Has Become a Thorn in Uber’s Side
articles.snippet: The Estonian ride-hailing company Bolt is an unexpected success story. The start-up points to Uber’s global challenges.
articles.abstract: The Estonian ride-hailing company Bolt is an unexpected success story. The start-up points to Uber’s global challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLINN, Estonia — Uber used to dominate ride-hailing in Poland and Kenya. Over the past two years, that started to change.

articles.headline: After the Bust, Are Bitcoins More Like Tulip Mania or the Internet?
articles.snippet: To understand where cryptocurrencies are going, it helps to look beneath the price gyrations to see how people are actually using the technology. The data provides reason for both hope and concern.
articles.abstract: To understand where cryptocurrencies are going, it helps to look beneath the price gyrations to see how people are actually using the technology. The data provides reason for both hope and concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When you talk to tech industry insiders about where Bitcoin is heading, two vastly different comparisons are inevitable: the tulip bulb and the internet.

articles.headline: On Census Citizenship Question, Supreme Court’s Conservatives Appear United
articles.snippet: Adding the question, government experts said, could depress participation in the census and affect how congressional seats are allocated.
articles.abstract: Adding the question, government experts said, could depress participation in the census and affect how congressional seats are allocated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed ready on Tuesday to allow the Trump administration to add a question on citizenship to the 2020 census, which critics say would undermine its accuracy by discouraging both legal and unauthorized immigrants from filling out the forms.

articles.headline: The Son Protested the Dictator. The Father Helped Throw Him Out.
articles.snippet: Lt. Gen. Salah Abdelkhalig is now among the most powerful men in Sudan, having ousted former president Omar Hassan al-Bashir at the urging of protesters like the general’s son.
articles.abstract: Lt. Gen. Salah Abdelkhalig is now among the most powerful men in Sudan, having ousted former president Omar Hassan al-Bashir at the urging of protesters like the general’s son.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — As protesters massed at the gates of Sudan’s military headquarters, calling for the ouster of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the country’s Air Force chief stepped outside to address them.
